ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Investigation of growth behavior and properties of Si nanowires grown at various supply times of Ar gas current

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Nano & Biotechnology Research Group, Faculty of Basic Science
Institute of High Voltage & High Current (IVAT)

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Silicon nanowires (SiNWs) were synthesized on gold-coated silicon substrates by a very high frequency plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition technique. The influence of supply time of Ar gas current on morphology, microstructure and optical properties of the SiNWs was investigated by means of field emission scanning electron microscopy, transmission electron microscopy, X-ray diffraction and photoluminescence. The lengths and density of the SiNWs decrease with an increase in the supply time of flowing Ar gas. The results revealed that the morphologies of the SiNWs strongly depended on the time of flowing Ar gas.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: One-dimensional (1D) materials have motivated great attention due to their benefits in basic scientific research and potential industrial applications. Such 1D materials play an important role in electronic and optoelectronic nanodevices. Among them, silicon nanowires (SiNWs) are one of the promising materials used as nanosensors, lithium batteries and field emission nanodevices [1–3]. Various techniques have been adopted to synthesize SiNWs, such as thermal evaporation [4], laser ablation [5], chemical vapor deposition (CVD) [6], etching techniques [7] and plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition (PECVD) [8]. PECVD has certain advantages such as lower growth temperatures compared with other methods. In our previous papers [9–11], it has been reported that high-quality SiNWs could be fabricated at temperatures below 450 °C in various conditions. Although there are many studies about structural changes of SiNWs with the variation of experimental conditions, according to our findings there is no report on the effect of Ar gas on the morphology of SiNWs.

In this study, the influence of the supply time of Ar gas current in the vapor–liquid–solid (VLS) mechanism on SiNWs has been investigated using a very high frequency plasma enhanced chemical vapor deposition (VHF-PECVD) technique. The SiNWs were characterized by using field emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM), energy dispersive X-ray spectrometry (EDX), high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), photoluminescence (PL) and Raman spectroscopy.

Section1.Heading: Experimental details
Section1.Para: The Au-catalyst SiNWs were synthesized on an n-type (111) silicon substrate by the vapor–liquid–solid mechanism using a 150 MHz very high frequency PECVD system. In the first step, the Si(111) substrate was cleaned in an ultrasonic bath of acetone and ethanol for 10 min. In the second step, the cleaned substrate was dipped into 0.1 % w/v poly-L lysine (PLL) and then rinsed with DI water and dried by pure nitrogen gas. Subsequently, the Au nanoparticles as a catalyst were deposited on the PLL-Si substrate. In the third step, silane (SiH4) gas with fixed flow rate was injected as the Si source in order to synthesize Si nanowires. Different samples were synthesized with different supply times of the Ar gas current to investigate the effect of the supply time of Ar gas. The RF power and the substrate temperature were kept at 15 W and 400 °C, respectively, during the growth of SiNWs.

The morphology of SiNWs is examined by a field emission scanning electron microscope (FESEM, JEOL JSM-6701F). The structure of the samples was analyzed by a high resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM, JEOL JEM-2100) with TEM operation voltage at 200 kV, X-ray diffraction (XRD) with Cu K
α radiation and an energy dispersive X-ray spectrometer (EDX). The optical properties were measured by a PL system at room temperature following excitation with a He–Cd laser (325 nm, 55 mW).

Section1.Heading: Results and discussion
Section1.Para:
To obtain detailed information regarding the morphology of as-synthesized SiNWs, FESEM measurement was carried out. Figure 1a–d show typical FESEM micrographs of the SiNWs synthesized on Au-coated Si substrates at 2, 4, 8 and 15 min supply times of Ar gas current, respectively. Highly dense nanowires were obtained for all four experimental conditions; however, the density of nanowires decreases with increase in time of Ar gas current. According to our calculation, the density of the nanowires decreases from in the order of 109/cm2 at 2 min supply time of Ar gas current to in the order of 107/cm2 at 15 min supply time of Ar gas current. All nanowires have a few nanometer-sized tips and 10-nanometer-sized roots.
Fig. 1
The FESEM morphologies of SiNWs on Si(111) substrates with different supply times of Ar gas current: (a) 2 min, (b) 4 min, (c) 8 min and (d) 15 min

The length distributions of the nanowires were plotted to quantitatively study the lengths of the grown nanowires. Figure 2a–d display the length distributions of the SiNWs grown at various supply times of Ar gas current. These diagrams reveal that with increasing supply time of Ar gas, the average length of SiNWs decreased considerably. As seen from Fig. 2a–d, SiNWs grown in 2 min of Ar supply time are larger in size compared to those grown at longer times of Ar supply. However, there can be seen a slight difference in the length distributions of nanowires at the Ar supply times of 2 and 4 min. Moreover, Fig. 2e shows a comparison of the length distributions of grown nanowires at various Ar supply times.
Fig. 2
Length distributions of SiNWs synthesized at (a) 2 min, (b) 4 min, (c) 8 min and (d) 15 min supply times of Ar gas current. (e) A comparison of the length distributions

The crystallinity and phase identification of the SiNWs have been determined by XRD analysis. Figure 3 shows the results of XRD analysis of samples grown at different supply times of Ar gas. As can be seen in Fig. 3, in all the cases sharp diffraction peaks corresponding to the Si(111) structure of the Si nanowires have been detected. There is a small broad peak due to Si oxide in all patterns. Au peaks in the pattern of Fig. 3 are due to Au droplets, with an average diameter in the range of 30 nm, on the silicon substrate that has been uniformly covered. The XRD pattern has shown the formation of crystalline structure of SiNWs. The peaks at 2θ=28.5∘, 47.4∘ and 56.2∘ have been identified as the (111), (220) and (311) planes of the crystallite.
Fig. 3
XRD patterns of SiNWs prepared at different Ar gas supply times: (a) 2 min, (b) 4 min, (c) 8 min and (d) 15 min

EDX analyses were performed on the SiNWs to investigate the composition of elements in the nanowires. Figure 4 displays EDX analyses on typical nanowires grown at 2 min of Ar gas supply time current. The corresponding EDX analyses showed mainly Si and Au elements, and traces of O element (80.00 %, 17.00 % and 2.00 %, respectively). Especially, the spectra taken from the tip of the nanowire revealed the Au element (Fig. 4a), while the stem of the nanowire is composed of Si and O elements (Fig. 4b). As seen in Fig. 4a, a higher intensity of the Si element was displayed in the nanowire stem in comparison with other elements. Furthermore, Fig. 4b shows a high-intensity peak for Si, that is, the amount of Si inside the nanowires is not comparable with the amounts of Au and O content in it. Meanwhile, the O content was slightly higher in intensity in the stem of nanowire while there is no trace of O in the tip of the nanowire. Since a copper grid and carbon tape was used in the EDX sample preparation, the Cu and C peaks were detected in the spectra.
Fig. 4
The EDX spectra of an Au-catalyzed Si nanowire grown at 2 min of the supply time of flowing Ar gas taken from (a) tip and (b) stem of the nanowire

For providing further information regarding the structural properties of as-grown Si nanowires, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) were performed. Figure 5 shows the typical result corresponding to 2 min processing time of Ar gas current. Regarding the low-magnification image (Fig. 5a) the nanowires have smooth surface topology for their overall length and tip diameter below 10 nm. This result is compatible with the FESEM measurements. The HRTEM measurement was performed to obtain detailed information regarding the crystallinity of as-synthesized SiNWs. According to Fig. 5b, a thick-set Si core and a thin amorphous outer layer with thicknesses of about 1–4 nm are the composition of the synthesized SiNW. The amorphous layer in the SiNW indicates the reaction of Si with oxygen in the air. The HRTEM (Fig. 5c) pattern reveals a very high crystallinity (single crystal) of the observed SiNWs. As seen in Fig. 5c, the lattice spacing calculated by using the TEM system reveals a lattice spacing of 0.314 nm, which is in good agreement with the (111) plane of single-crystalline Si. Moreover, the direction of the Si nanowire is determined using the HRTEM pattern along with the lattice fringe spacing. It can also be found from Fig. 4b that the growth direction of this nanowire is along the 〈111〉 direction.
Fig. 5
(a) Low-magnification TEM image of a single nanowire capped by Au-catalyst nanoparticle, (b) HRTEM characterization of a SiNW grown at 2 min processing time of Ar gas current, (c) enlarged image of the zone indicated by a red square in (b), (d) electron diffraction patterns of selected area on region presented in (b) (red square in (b))

The PL spectra measurements were performed at room temperature to understand the optical properties of the as-grown SiNWs. A typical PL spectrum obtained from synthesized SiNWs is shown in Fig. 6. This figure reveals two PL peaks; a sharp peak and a broad peak centered respectively at 475 nm and 590 nm. These results are similar to the results of other researchers [12]. It reveals that the sharp peak (475 nm) is attributed to silicon oxide and the local structural defects related to oxygen where the defect is due to high oxygen deficiency [12, 13]. The broad emission peak (590 nm) found in previous reports [14–16] is due to quantum confinement. Usually, the quantum confinement happens in small-size (<10 nm) nanocrystalline structures. However, in our experiment, the average diameter is larger than 10 nm; therefore, it cannot be considered as due to a small-size nanocrystalline structure. These PL emission bands are related to the emission by point defects in the nanowire lattice, such as oxygen vacancies, oxygen interstitials and anti-site defects.
Fig. 6
Room-temperature PL spectra of the produced SiNWs at (a) 2 min, (b) 4 min, and (c) 8 min supply times of Ar gas current

In order to further investigate the crystallinity of the nanowire structure, Raman spectroscopy was performed. Figure 7 displays the Raman spectra of typical nanowires grown at various supply times of Ar gas. A narrow and asymmetrical peak is shown in all spectra. The asymmetry of Raman peaks usually is due to nanoscale size and defects [17]. There is a sharp peak at the 518.4 cm−1 position in the Raman spectra of the sample. It is the first-order transverse optical (TO) phonon mode [18]. This indicates the presence of a high crystal quality Si in the nanowire samples.
Fig. 7
Raman spectra of the SiNWs synthesized at 2 min of the supply time of flowing Ar gas

A metal catalyst is often required to grow SiNWs. The role of the catalyst to encourage the growth of single crystal SiNWs is necessary in the VLS mechanism. The catalyst should be chosen carefully to achieve this consequence. In other words, the catalyst strongly affects the growth mechanism, crystal structure and the axial growth. In the case of silicon, for example, in order for it to be absorbed by the catalyst it needs to be highly solvable in the chosen metal. Since, in this research, the investigated growth temperature was 400 °C based on the EDX and TEM results, the nanowires are expected to grow via the VLS mechanism.

The axial growth rate, R axial, of the SiNWs depends on the ratio of NW length, Δl NW, and deposition time, t d. Based on the above results, the estimated R axial decreased from 200±25 to 33.3±5 nm/min for an increase in the supply time of Ar gas current from 2 to 15 min. According to the FESEM results, synthesized SiNWs at longer supply time of Ar gas current have smaller length. Moreover, the radial growth rate, R radial, of NWs is calculated from the difference in bottom radius (r bottom) and top radius (r top) of NWs, that is, Δr NW=r bottom−r top, per unit t d. Therefore, the tapering parameter of the NWs, T p, defined as the ratio of R radial and R axial, that is, T p=R radial/R axial, can be calculated [19]. By referring to our results, the calculated T p increased from 35.3 nm/μm to 200.4 nm/μm for a supply time of Ar gas current change from 2 to 15 min, which shows that a supply time of Ar gas current will lead to the synthesis of more tapered NWs. The less tapered SiNWs are mainly due to the higher R axial at lower supply time of Ar gas current.

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: Needle-like Si nanowires were successfully grown on Si substrates by the VHF-PECVD method. Increasing the supply time of Ar gas current has a strong effect on the morphologies and shapes of the grown nanowires. When the supply time of Ar gas current increases from 2 to 15 min the density of SiNWs decreases and the nanowires become shorter. Furthermore, based on the TEM and EDX results, the growth mechanism of the SiNWs was described in terms of the VLS mechanism. Some diffraction peaks related to Si nanostructure were observed in the XRD patterns, indicating the high crystallinity of the grown SiNWs. The HRTEM and Raman spectra confirmed the SiNWs with a crystalline core and a thinner amorphous outer shell. Finally, less tapered SiNWs were obtained at a lower supply time of Ar gas current (2 min).
